p.s: The purpose of this experiment is to explore the relationship between the forms of Newton's 2nd Law appropriate to linear motion and to rotational motion, explore the physical behaviour of 2nd moment of mass and to develop understanding of the nature of experimental error and the analysis of experiment data.
The moment of inertia of the three discs is to be determined by experiments and compared with one obtained from a theoretical relationship.
The method used is by measuring the time for a weight to fall a distance when attach to a moment arm that is attached to a disc.
The moment of inertia of the three discs is for the 75mm disc, for the 63.50mm disc and for 50mm disc.
Comparing the results with those derived from the theoretical relationship it is found to be consistent with a maximum percentage of error of 7%.
It is found that the Newton's 2nd law does hold for rotational motion.
The 2nd moment of mass of an object is proportional to the mass and radius of the object.

div2.head: Methods used to determine the Constants of this experiment

p.s: After investigating the apparatus provided and the theory behind the experiment, I have decided measure the time for the weight to fall through a distance L.
The length L is set as the distance from the table to the botttom of the mass hanger when the string is fully wrapped around the moment arm.
The reason is because it is easier to know the exact moment to stop the stopwatch when the mass hanger hit the table as the impact of the mass hanger on the table will certainly be audible.
The height of the hanger is fixed by the position of the "knot" of the string that ties the hanger to the arm.
The initial position for the "knot" will be just touching the moment arm when winded.
Which are also exactly 8 loops the string make around the moment arm.
In order to measure this distance accurately the distance of the "knot" on the string from the moment arm when the bottom of the weight hanger is just touching the table is measured.
This is because instead of aimlessly waving the ruler around trying to ensure it is perpendicular to the table, the ruler can use the string as a guide.
The other measurement needed is the radius r of the moment arm.
The radius r of the moment arm is small compared to the sensitivity of the meter rule.
Therefore an alternative method has been devised to determine the radius r.
Three measurements is needed to be taken

Comparing the moment of inertia of the three disc calculated from experimental results with those that is derive using the theoretical formula, it is found that all three values calculated from the theory lays within the range of experimental results.
The mean moment of Inertia for each disc is very close to the theoretical prediction with at most deviation.
This error and uncertainly might be contributed by the following assumptions
The applied torque is assumed to be constant.
While this assumption is perfectly reasonable, it does introduce a certain amount of error to the final result.
In actual case the torque does varies a little because of air resistance.
In order to improve the result, where possible conduct this experiment in vacuum.
The apparatus is assumed to be perfect.
The bearings are assumed to be frictionless.
However in actual case, the bearings does have an opposing force that resists motion.
In order to improve the experimental results I would recommend putting oil on moving parts of the apparatus to reduce frictional forces from influencing the results.
One other assumption made is that the linear acceleration is constant.
This assumption is made so that a can be expressed in terms of constant linear acceleration formula.
By having a means of directly measuring the angular acceleration might improve the accuracy of results.
With the percentage of uncertainty and error at most 7% for the smallest disc and only 5% for the largest disc the results obtained from this experiment is fairly reliable.
Given that the theory behind the experiment is correct, I am fairly confident with the values obtained.
This is especially true for the larger discs.
